dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large and very comfortable office over-looking St. Patr Cathedral. At the moment the office is filled to bursting with men and women, slumped in chairs, sitting on desks, of them very tense. Among the crowd of people we note: MU FISHER, a young and very ambitious junior executive and  PHYLLIS BERNARD, an attractive woman in her early thirtie She is a lawyer with the agency. At the moment, TED KRAMER, nice-looking without being wha you would call a matinee idol, paces back and forth. His is loosened, he checks his watch every fifteen seconds.  Clearly he is very distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (predicting the worst) They're not gonna call... I tell you  they're not gonna call. I blew it. I  don't know what I did wrong, but I В–

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON JIM O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Ted's boss and good friend. He is in his middle fifties,  nattily dressed with the slightly bleary look of a heavy  drinker. He sits back in his chair with his feet propped the desk and a drink in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not unfriendly) Ted, will you take it easy? Revlon's  not about to drop an account that  represents more than two million in  gross billing receipts in a small  agency like this, without making us  sweat. Now just relax, okay?  Everything's gonna be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at this stage, nothing  will help) I don't think so, Jim. Maybe I  shouldn't have В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound-effect: The phone rings. Everyone freezes. As O'Con reaches for the phone,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark, the only light coming from a small nigh light. We SEE a beautiful five year old boy (BILLY KRAMER). He l in bed, half asleep. HOLD FOR A BEAT as a beautiful woman (JOANNA KRAMER) leans over, kisses the child and hugs him tightly to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intense) I love you, Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drowsy) I love you too, mommy... Good-night...

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: She gets up from the bed and starts toward the door of th child's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep tight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the bedbugs bite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna stops in the doorway, silhouetted against the ligh She turns, takes a last look at her son, then steps outsi

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: Now that the light is brighter, we can SEE her more clear In her mid-thirties, she is beautiful, dressed in a style that can best be described as Bloomingdale's. HOLD FOR A  BEAT as she leans against the door. It is clear from her  expression that she is terribly upset. Then, making up he mind, she crosses to a closet and takes out a suitcase. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HER as she carries it into the bed lays it out on the bed and opens it. PAN WITH HER as she crosses to a closet, grabs an armload clothes and dumps them helter-skelter into the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a few minutes later, the news has obviously been go because there is a general celebration in progress. Jim O'Connor, now standing, raises one hand for silence,  then making a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to Ted Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers and good-natured jokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting an arm around  Ted squeezing him  tight) I wanna tell you something about  this little runt. He went out there  and sold the shit out of Revlon and  that's why we got the account. It  was his idea, it was his concept,  right down the line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More hoots and cheers. People start to yell "Speech."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, but  cannot stop grinning) All I can say... All I can say is  this is maybe one of the five best  days of my whole life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna stands at the medicine cabinet, going through it,  packing things in a travel kit: rollers, deodorant, makeu birth control pills. She starts to take a small bottle of perfume that has only an eighth of an inch of fluid left  inside, hesitates, then puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now some time has passed, most of the crowd has gone and  only the regulars are left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the middle of a  story) So anyway Jim and I are making the  pitch, right? And all of a sudden  this old guy starts to cough and I  keep on going and he keeps on coughing  and I keep on going and he keeps on  coughing and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray Fisher leans over, shakes Ted's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Congratulations, Ted. That was a  hell of a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Where you goin' Murray, it's early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at his watch) Oh, Christ, I'm late... I gotta get  out of here. (however, instead of  going, he settles  back and resumes his  story) So anyway, I look over and this old  geezer is starting to turn blue and  I swear to God the only thing I can  think about is that this poor  sonofabitch is gonna die on me and  screw up the pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: A long and meticulous list that Joanna is making of the phone numbers and addresses of doctors and hospita of what the various medicines are for, and of the foods t Billy is and isn't permitted to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joanna puts the finishing touches on the list and care arranges it on top of the kitchen counter next to a box o unsweetened, whole grain cereal and a jar of honey. Note: It is this same set of notes that Ted will later  unthinkingly throw away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the doors to the outer lobby open and Ted and O'Connor appear. Ted starts to hail a cab, O'Connor stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's the rush? C'mon, walk me  a couple of blocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, I've got to go. I'm already  late В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Ted... I just want to tell  you, when old man Schmidt retires  next year, I've got a pretty good  feeling they'll kick me upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and starts to walk off down the street, Ted, of  course, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and when they do, I just want you  to know I'm takin' you along with  me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: As she goes through her jewelry case, taking some things, leaving others. In the B.G. we SEE a framed photograph of Billy, smiling, looking into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Tracking with them as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling no pain) Y'know, Ted, I mean what I said back  there. You did a hell of a job on  this and I want you to know I'm  turning the whole show over to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it Ted, you're running this  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suitcase is now full. Joanna zips it shut and looks a to make sure that she hasn't forgotten anything. Then, she hefts her suitcase and starts out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna carries in the suitcase, sets it by the front door then she crosses to the living room and sits down at the  dining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes out a list made on the back of an old envelope. she begins to review it, checking off some items: OFF SCREEN Sound: A key turning in the lock. As Joanna looks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door swings open to reveal Ted Kramer, an enormous grin on his face, a bottle of champagne in his hand. He i so full of himself that he doesn't notice there is anythi wrong. Note: Throughout the entire scene he carries the bottle o champagne, never putting it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you might just like to  know that at five-fifteen this  afternoon we were officially handed  the Fire and Ice account by Revlon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she takes a deep  breath, then:) Ted, I'm leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That represents a gross billing in  excess of two million В– (hearing her) What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna opens her purse, takes out her keys and wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are my keys. I won't be needing  them any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: Ted does not for a moment believe that his wife wil really leave him. All he can think of right now is that h will have to spend the rest of the evening coping with on of her moods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic) I'm sorry I'm late, all right? I'm  sorry I didn't call В– I was busy  making a living.

dialogues.speaker: CROSS-CUTTING BETWEEN THEM
dialogues.text: Joanna doesn't even bother to look up at him. She opens h purse, takes out her wallet and begins removing credit ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My American Express... My  Bloomingdale's Credit Card... My  check book В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the martyr) Okay, okay... What is it this time?  What did I do now?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring this) I took two thousand out of the savings  account. That was what I had in the  bank when we got married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna, whatever it is, believe me,  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are the slips for the laundry  and the cleaning. They'll be ready  on Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard lining it) Now listen, before you do something  you'll really regret you'd better  stop and think -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not bothering to  look up) I've paid the rent, the Con-Ed and  the phone bill, so you don't have to  worry about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checks off the last item on her list as her husband  watches, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, that's everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna gets to her feet and starts toward the front door. an instant Ted is after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic starting) For God's sake, Joanna, would you at  least tell me what I did that's so  terrible! Would you do me that little  favor?

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: At the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's not your fault, okay?  It's me. It's my fault В– you just  married the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (placating her) So we've got problems. Everybody's  got problems В– that's normal В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna opens the door and they step out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, you're not listening to me.  It's over, finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening, Joanna В– believe me,  I'm listening. My wife is walking  out on me after eight years of В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter) You just don't get it, do you? (as though to a child) I В– am В– really В– and В– truly В–  leaving В– you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you, Joanna. I promise I  heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you didn't. (quietly) You didn't even ask about Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffening) What about Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking him with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears start) Ted, I can't... I tried... I really  tried but... I just can't hack it  anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Joanna, you don't mean that.  You're a terrific mother В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from her gut) I am not! I'm a terrible mother! I'm  an awful mother. I yell at him all  the time. I have no patience. No...  No. He's better off without me. (unable to look at  Ted) Ted, I've got to go... I've got to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) Okay, I understand and I promise I  won't try and stop you, but you can't  just go... Look, come inside and  talk... Just for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) NO!... Please... Please don't make  me stay... I swear... If you do,  sooner or later... maybe tomorrow,  maybe next week... maybe a year from  now... (looking directly at  him) I'll go right out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound-effect: The elevator approaching.

dialogues.speaker: CROSS-CUTTING BETWEEN THEM
dialogues.text: There is nothing more that can be done, this is the last  moment of intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens, Joanna steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to help you get a  cab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna shakes her head. The elevator door closes behind h and it starts to descend.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED KRAMER
dialogues.text: He stands for a moment, stunned, unable to move. Then he  turns and races back into the apartment. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM as he rushes across to one of living room windows, throws it open and leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down to the street from the eighth floor. We SEE  Joanna step off the curb and hail a passing taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Joanna!?... Joanna?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either she doesn't hear him or else she pays no attention She gets into the cab, closes the door behind her and it  drives away.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he stands for a moment watching the taxi as it disappe Then, slowly, he closes the window, turns, and AS THE CAM TRACKS WITH HIM, walks into the bedroom. The bedroom is a mess: the closet door stands open, insid Joanna's section is empty except for some shoe-boxes and few dresses that are scattered across the floor. Several  dresser drawers have been pulled out and their contents  emptied. HOLD IN A WIDE SHOT as Ted wearily picks up one of the dr and hangs it back on its hanger in its proper place, read for Joanna's return. As he continues straightening up the room, THE CAMERA SLOWLY FADES TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Kramer paces back and forth, eyeing the phone. Then,  coming to a decision, he crosses to it, picks up the rece and starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is dark except for the Kramer apartment whic is ablaze with lights. HOLD as we HEAR: Sound: The phone ringing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously asleep) Huh... Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (righteous) All right, Thelma... That's it. I've  had it. You can call your good friend  Joanna Kramer and tell her enough is  enough, okay? I mean, I don't know  what I did, but you can tell her  she's made her point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, what are you talking about?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't play innocent with me, Thelma.  You know perfectly well what's going  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Ted, I don't understand a word you're  saying. Where's Joanna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound-effect, as Ted slams down the receiver. Instantly a light is turned on two floors below.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: As we HEAR: Sound-effect: the doorbell rings. A moment later Ted opens the door and THELMA PHILLIPS ent She is a neighbor (Apt. 6-B) and Joanna Kramer's best fri About four months ago Thelma and her husband Charley were divorced. Until then the two families had been very close, the Kram son (Billy) being about the same age as the Phillips' daughte (Kim). With the divorce, however, the Kramers tried to remain fr with both Thelma and Charley and that has caused a certai amount of friction. Thelma is an attractive woman in her mid-thirties. She dr well, works out religiously at Jack LaLanne's and goes to therapist twice a week. She is also given to acting the l analyst with her friends. Thelma is generous with her adv sharing the wealth so to speak. With all of this she is k loyal and a loving friend. At the moment, however, she is all business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around,  suspiciously) All right. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: From his attitude it is clear that there is no love lost  between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Thelma, you want to know  what's going on? I'll tell you what's  going on. I'll tell you exactly what's  going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Ted, all I В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to really  roll) I came home tonight. We just got the  Fire and Ice account at the agency.  Do you know what that means?! Do you  understand what that means? It means  that it was maybe one of the five  best days in my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, all I wanted to know was where  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not letting her get  a word in edgewise) I walk in the house and before I can  say "How are you?", "Did you have a  nice day?" before I can say anything.  Pow she's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OhmyGod. Didn't she say anything?  She must've said something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah, she said it wasn't any use  talking anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, don't be so hostile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted draws himself upright with the dignity of the Ambassa to the Court of St. James. However, during the following, begins pounding the pillows on the couch into shape with  real vehemence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hostile? (pow) Me? (whack) Thelma, I'm not hostile. (thud) I am anything but hostile. (sock) But if you want to know what I am.  I'll tell you what I am. What I am  is, I am hurt. I am very hurt. And I  just want to know one thing, okay?  Just one thing... Why? That's all I  want to know... Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (how to say this) Ted, Joanna and I used to talk a lot  and... well, she told me a lot of...  ah, things about the two of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly nervous) Things? What kind of things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly she knows  more than she's  willing to say) I mean... things. Ted, Joanna's very  unhappy and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flash of anger) Listen, Joanna Kramer's got a goddamn  good life. She's got a husband that  loves her. She's got a terrific kid.  She's got a wonderful home В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting mad herself) What d'you know about how Joanna  felt? You went off to an office every  morning and you'd come dragging home  at seven or eight every night and as  long as dinner was on the table you  thought everything was swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it ever occur to you guys that  Joanna Kramer's not the easiest person  in the world to live with?! Did it?!  For one thing she's always thirty  minutes late. You can set your watch  by it В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) So she's late. What's the big deal.  That's just a way of saying, "Pay  attention to me."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not listening) Two. She is getting to be a real  hermit or recluse or whatever it is  you call it. Thelma, do you know  where I could be in this business if  I had a wife that entertained or  went out socially В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for shit's sake, Ted, you are the  most selfish human being I have ever  met. No wonder she said you came  first, then Billy, then, if there  was anything left over, she got the  scraps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how come she never said anything  like that to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she didn't feel like she should  have to. Maybe she felt like if you'd  been paying any real attention to  her to start with, maybe you would've  noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung) Boy, you guys are really something,  y'know? I'd like to know one thing,  okay В– just one little thing. Did  you tell Joanna she should leave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and starts toward the front door, Ted at her he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know something Thelma В– you are  the typhoid Mary of divorce. I mean  it. Joanna and I never had any trouble  until you and Charley split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, divorce is a terrible thing. I  know, I went through it. You've got  to believe I did everything I could  to get Joanna to stay. (pause) But I'll tell you something. You may  not want to hear it, but it took a  lot of courage for Joanna to do what  she just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know what the hell kind  of courage it takes to walk out on  your husband and your child?

dialogues.speaker: THELMA
dialogues.text: That stops her dead in her tracks. She had always assumed that Joanna took Billy with her when she left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna left Billy? She didn't take  him with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted shakes his head. There is a long beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned, quiet) Oh Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a beautiful sunny morning and the super stands in f of the building hosing down the sidewalk. HOLD as a garba truck enters FRAME and the garbage men begin loading sack of trash into the back of the truck. As it begins to grin up the garbage with an ungodly sound, THE CAMERA PANS UP THE EIGHTH FLOOR WINDOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Kramer lies in his bed, fast asleep. HOLD FOR A BEAT as we HEAR: OFF SCREEN Sound: From the street below, the garbage truc grinding up garbage. A moment later, Billy opens his eyes, struggles to his fe and, AS THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM, trudges sleepily out of hi room, across the hall and into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the child stands in front of the toilet, eyes closed,

dialogues.speaker: HEAR
dialogues.text: OFF SCREEN Sound-effect: as the child pees noisily. Then, when he is finished, he turns and, without botherin to flush the toilet, shuffles down the hall and into his  parents' bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed is empty, there is no sign that anyone has slept it.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: A look of suspicion on his face, he turns and starts back down the hall toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy enters, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Kramer, still fully dressed, looking like the wrath o God is asleep in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he marches across to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's mommy?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: His eyes open, he looks around startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?... Oh God... What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) The little hand is on the six and  the big hand is on the nine. Where  is mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to pull himself  together) Oh, Christ... Ah, yeah... you want  to know why mom's not here, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bullshit) Okay, I'm going to tell you... It's  like this. Mommy and daddy had a  little argument and mommy decided  she wanted to go off by herself for  a little while. You know how sometimes  you get mad and want to go off and  be by yourself? Well, it's like that,  okay? Okay. (subject closed) Now how about some breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted struggles to his feet and THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH THEM they start toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is mommy coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) Soon. Very soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they are inside the kitchen, Ted looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, on the kitchen cabinet is a box of "natural grain" cereal, a jar of honey, some wheat germ, and a banana, wi carefully written instructions from Joanna underneath.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He takes one look at the note, crumples it up and tosses in the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the camp counselor) I'll tell you what, kiddo В– why don't  I fix us some French toast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Wow! French toast, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the camp counselor) Sure. Didn't I ever tell you French  toast was my specialty? I'll bet I  never told you that. Now then, the  first thing we need is... (trying desperately  to remember) ...eggs! Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy nods. Ted opens the refrigerator and takes some egg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is terrific... isn't this  terrific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted begins the process of making French toast, it soon becomes obvious that he has no idea of what he is doing.  What follows is a symphony in incompetence on Ted's part. breaks the eggs into a bowl and ends up with most of the  shell mixed up with the egg. Then he takes a piece of bread and drops it into bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (saying it will make  it so) I'm having a good time... Are you  having a good time?

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Watching all of this with increasing apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forgot the milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still the camp  counselor) That's right. You're absolutely  right... It's been a long time since  I made French toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted takes a container of milk, pours it into the bowl so  that it is filled to the brim. Then he sloshes the bread  around until it is half-dissolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this, isn't this something?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lops off a huge hunk of butter, drops it into an omele pan and turns up the flame.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Watching. He looks as though he is about to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my orange juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the counterman) Right. One O.J. coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the refrigerator and starts to get the orange ju As he does, black smoke begins to billow ominously from t frying pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) Daddy!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted turns, spots the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry... Everything's fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges for the handle of the frying pan, which by now very hot. He grabs it, lets out a howl of pain and the wh mess, frying pan, butter, bread, goes crashing to the flo

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Suddenly all the rage comes pouring out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddam! Son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted kneels down and begins to clean up the mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself as much  as to Billy) It's okay. It's gonna be okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: ON A BUS
dialogues.text: As it pulls to a stop. The doors open and a stream of mot and children get off. Among them we spot Ted Kramer with  Billy. As they start across the street, Ted reaches down takes hold of Billy's hand. The moment they get to the fa side, Billy takes his hand away from Ted's and wipes it o his pants. Clearly Ted's hands are very sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start down the block toward Billy's school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is mommy coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. I told you before, very soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) Will she pick me up after school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. If I'm not here, you go home  with Thelma and Kim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she forgets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weary) I'll call Thelma and remind her,  okay? Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for a few steps, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what happens if she's on her way  to school and she gets runned over  by a truck and killed? What happens  them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at Billy in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the two of them enter the school and disappear from vi

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: As they open and Ted steps out looking like the wrath of  God. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM as he crosses the waiting room toward the inner offices.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Glancing up as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerful) Congratulations, Mr. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Looking at her like she has lost her mind. Nevertheless h continues on, passing through swinging doors into a long  corridor lined with secretaries' desks and offices leadin off of it. Suddenly a younger man rushes up, grabs Ted's hand and st to pump it vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific news, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another nut. Ted smiles at the man, humoring him and cont toward his office. O'Connor appears, throwing his arm aro Ted, squeezing him in a bear hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... Look who was out celebrating  last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ted realizes that all these people are congratul him for getting the Fire and Ice account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to appear  nonchalant) Uh, Jim... Can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and O'Connor sitting across from one another. O'Conno has just heard the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. That's a real  blockbuster. (shakes his head) I always figured you guys had it  made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morose) You want to know the real kicker?  The real kicker is, for the first  time in my life В– the first time В– I  feel like a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connor nods sympathetically. Actually he is praying tha Ted won't start to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff upper lip) Listen, don't let it get you down. (doesn't believe it  for a second) You're going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toujour gai) Me? I've never been better. I mean  having my wife walk out on me after  seven years of marriage agrees with  me just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Ted, I'm the oldest whore on  the beat, okay? Three marriages, two  divorces... You're gonna be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wishful thinking) I'm going to be okay. The way I see  it, Joanna'll come home, it's just a  matter of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) She'll be back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods in agreement. There is a beat of silence as both men consider Joanna's imminent return. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be tactful) But... just in case... I mean, just  on the off chance she doesn't. What  are you going to do about the kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the wind goes out of  him) I don't know, Jim. This whole thing  has happened so... Pow В– like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a friend having to  say something very  difficult) Look, it's none of my business, so  you can tell me to butt out, okay?  But if you want my advice, you'll  send Billy away to stay with relatives  for a while. Just until you get  yourself straightened out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) I don't know, Jim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the Dutch uncle) Ted, this may sound a little rough,  but we've just landed the biggest  account in the history of this agency,  right? And now it's up to us В– that's  you and me В– to deliver the goods.  Ted, you're my main man, and if I  can't depend on you a hundred and  ten percent, twenty-four hours a  day, because you're worried about a  kid with a runny nose В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, I appreciate what you're saying.  I mean it, but I really think Joanna's  coming back.

dialogues.speaker: ON O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Clearly he doesn't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're right, Ted... I really  hope you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is postmarked Denver, Colorado. The letter is addresse to Billy Kramer and it is from Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he rips open the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy!

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: He sits in the living room watching television, a chocola doughnut in one hand and a remote control device for watc television in the other. Off-screen Sound: a Saturday morning kiddie program from television set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (focused on T.V.) Uh, huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a letter from mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly, Billy turns down the volume of the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) When is she coming home?!

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he starts to read, slowly, carefully, so that Billy ca absorb it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My dear, sweet Billy: Mommy has  gone away. Sometimes in the world  daddies go away and mommies bring up  their little boys. But sometimes a  mommy can go away too, and you have  your daddy to bring you up."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted continues to read, Billy starts turning up the sou on the television, using the remote control device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his voice so  he can be heard) "I have gone away because I must  find some interesting things to do  for myself in the world. Everybody  has to, and so do I. Being your mommy  was one thing, but there are other  things and this is what I have to  do. I did not get a chance to tell  you this, and that is why I am writing  you now."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the volume from the television is so loud that Ted has to shout to make himself heard over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I will always be your mommy and I  will always love you. I just won't  be your mommy in the house. But I  will be your mommy of the heart. And  I... " (he looks up, about  to tell the child to  lower the volume) Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits, watching television with an almost ferocious  intensity on his face, doing his best to block out Ted's  voice.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He watches his son for a second, then carefully refolds t letter, puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he reaches across,  turns down the sound  on the T.V.) It's okay... It's okay. We'll talk  about it some other time.

dialogues.speaker: THELMA
dialogues.text: Reading Joanna's letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... OhmyGod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes the letter, looks up at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Thel... This whole  thing has happened so... Pow, like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, what are you going to do  about Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff) I'm gonna keep him, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is nothing personal, but  I don't think you can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma, I've lost my wife, I'm not  losing my child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing off) All right... Okay... But let's get  something straight, right now. I  mean, I'm sorry about what happened  between you and Joanna, but it's not  my problem, understand?

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON TED
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to have you calling  every fifteen minutes just because  you can't find a hot water bottle,  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got enough trouble raising my  own kid. I don't need another one.  Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on your own, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: ON THELMA
dialogues.text: A long pause, she looks at him with all the warmth of a t sergeant facing a raw recruit. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Who's Billy's pediatrician?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He hasn't the foggiest idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (machine-gun delivery) Ed Davies. 230 East 76th Street. 472- 8227. Fifty bucks a house call, thirty  for an office visit. Write this down:  I'm not telling you twice. What's  the nearest hospital?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he grabs a piece of paper and starts writing frantical

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not waiting) Lenox Hill. 77th Street between Park  and Lex. The emergency number is 327- 0800.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down... Slow down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands in the middle of the room, sorting out a huge  pile of dirty clothes. Thelma sits on the edge of the bed watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colors in one pile, white things in  another and shirts in a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the BACKGROUND we SEE the bathroom door as it opens an Billy Kramer steps out, freshly bathed and wearing clean  clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking around) Brush the teeth. Hang up the towel  and flush the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy immediately turns on his heels and heads back into bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: A SILVER CIGARETTE BOX
dialogues.text: That is inscribed, "Ted and Joanna Kramer, Married April
HOLD FOR A BEAT then Ted's hand reaches into FRAME and pi it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he takes the cigarette box and balances it on a stack scrap books, photographs, ash trays, etc., etc., that he carrying. He crosses to another table, picks up a framed  photograph of Joanna and Billy and piles that on top of  everything. We realize that Ted is going through the apar from top to bottom and methodically cleaning out every tr of Joanna that he can find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted goes through the room, picking up Billy's clothes  which have been strewn every which way. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM as he carries them into Billy' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is fast asleep, the only light coming from the nigh lamp on the dresser. Ted dumps the soiled clothing in a  hamper, hangs up Billy's jacket, then he neatly folds the boy's sweater and crosses to the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted opens a drawer and starts to put the sweater away. Suddenly he spots something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, in the drawer, sitting on top of a pile of clothin is one of the photographs of Joanna that Ted put away thi afternoon. Billy has retrieved it and hidden it here, hoping that Te wouldn't find it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: As he takes a long look at the photograph, then turns to son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy asleep, tangled up in the covers.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He removes the photograph from the drawer, crosses to the bed and places it on the nightstand nearby so that Billy  will be able to see the picture of Joanna when he wakes u in the morning. He sits for a moment longer on the side o the bed and reaches across and smooths down his son's rum hair.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Clearly in a rush, loading his briefcase with work to do  that evening. He starts for the door and THE CAMERA TRACK WITH HIM as he walks along the outer office corridor, hea for the elevator. As he passes the door to O'Connor's off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) 'Night, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Hey, Ted. C'mon in. I wanna' talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly Ted stops, turns around and walks back to the door to O'Connor's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connor sits back in his chair, his feet propped on the  desk a drink in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jovial) What's the big rush. C'mon in, put  your feet up, have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON TED
dialogues.text: Hanging in the doorway, clearly anxious to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it tonight. Gotta pick up  Billy. I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (paying no attention  to that) Listen, I heard a terrific joke today.  There's this Polish skydiver В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) Sorry, Jim I've got to go. I'll talk  to you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And before O'Connor can say anything he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Obviously displeased. He sits for a moment, drumming his  fingers on the desk top, then reaches for the phone and s to dial. A moment later:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray? Jim O'Connor, why don't you  drop by and have a drink...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted emerges from the building, starts to hail a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cab pulls to a stop. Ted leaps out and rushes insi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open and Ted steps out. THE CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he crosses to the doorway of apartment, rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door is opened by a pleasant-looking woman in her  thirties. This is MRS. KLINE. She has the slightly haggard look of  someone who has just survived a birthday party with eight five-year-olds. In fact, behind her we SEE an abundance of crepe paper an balloons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic) Mrs. Kline, I'm sorry I'm late, but  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, but I'm afraid  Billy was a little nervous... (she glances off screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, his coat on, his goody bag in his lap sits alone o bench in the foyer. The moment he sees his father, he gets up and starts for door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted, accusingly) You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, pal, but I had a meeting  and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Kline anxious  to get away) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Bill. Thank you for coming. (calling out to her  son in the next room) Mark. Say goodbye to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he hustles his father out into the hallway. Once door shut behind them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen) I was waiting a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have crossed to the elevator. Ted rings the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this ain't exactly  the greeting he's  expected) It wasn't so long, I'm only... (checking his watch) ...twenty minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the other mothers got here a  long time ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the doors close, blocking them from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Billy sit at the dining table, a large pizza betw them. Ted is working hard, trying to establish some kind of rap with his son. Billy is silent, he picks at the slice of p in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more of the camp  counselor) How was school today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Same as usual...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, don't eat with your fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (morose) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like pulling teeth) Well, I see the Yankees finally won  a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I mean dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be excused? I'm not hungry. I  think I'll go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Too much birthday cake, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he gets up from  the table) I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy shuffles off toward his room. Ted sits for a bea picking at the food on his plate. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH BILLY as he gets up from the table and walks into his room. HOLD IN THE DOORWAY as he takes his shirt and pants and leaves them lying on the floor. T boy crosses to the closet, gets his pajamas and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON TED
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: He starts to crawl into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aloof) 'Night.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS WITH HIM as he crosses to where Billy dro his clothes on the floor, picks them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, pal, I'm sorry, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Ted crosses, sits on the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I remember one time when. I  was a couple of years younger than  you are now and... I was staying  with this cousin of mine and my  parents were supposed to come and  pick me up by three, but it got later  and later and they didn't and they  didn't show up and I remember I got  really scared that something had  happened to them and I remember when  they finally came instead of being  happy to see them I was very angry  and... Billy, I promise I'll never  do that to you again, okay?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is turned to the wall. HOLD FOR A BEAT as we SEE him nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: The following scene, which is written as one, is  actually to be played so that each time we cut back to th woman who is being interviewed as housekeeper, it is a  different woman: sometimes nervous and excited, sometimes large and lugubrious, with six shopping bags, sometimes  looking like a headmistress at Dachau. They are uniformly (until the last) unappetizing. Throughout this, we SEE Ted becoming increasingly despera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around nervous) It's very big... They didn't tell me  it was this big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically) No... No, actually it's only two  bedrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing) Phew... This place is a real pig  sty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Look, my wife just walked out on me.  Okay? It's been a tough week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me your troubles, mister.  I got enough of my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: With the FOURTH WOMAN we begin on a CLOSEUP and PUL BACK to REVEAL that we are in Ted's office and it is the  middle of the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing is, I don't do floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that point the door behind her opens and O'Connor poke his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Or windows. I come in at ten and I  get Wednesdays off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brisk) I'll be with you in a minute, Jim. (back to the woman) You couldn't make that Saturday,  could you?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FIFTH WOMAN, (MRS. WILLEWSKA)
dialogues.text: She is a slightly built attractive woman in her early six There is a long pause as she looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of boy is your son?

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: This is the first person that ever asked about Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Well, he's... ah, he's a good kid.  He's shy and... I think he's probably  very creative and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He's right in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start toward the child's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkness we can SEE Billy, all scrunched up in the covers. HOLD FOR A BEAT as the door opens and the light from the  hall falls across the sleeping boy.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Ted and Mrs. Willewska stand silhouetted against the ligh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... He's very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he stirs, in his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, you are a very lucky  man.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION, TED
dialogues.text: This is the first time since Joanna left that this has  occurred to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Willewska, could you start on  Monday?

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY AND TED
dialogues.text: TRACKING JUST IN FRONT OF THEM as they wheel a shopping c along the aisle. Ted has a shopping list in his hand. Ted stops, takes a box of detergent off of the shelf, sta to put it in the shopping cart, when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Mom, I mean dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mind elsewhere) Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the right soap. We use  the kind in the green and yellow  box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, there's not much difference В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) We use the green and yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at his son for a moment, then carefully replace the detergent that he had originally picked and reaches f the green and yellow kind. dialogues.text: (looking in the  direction of the  voice) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk him over to Bethesda Fountain,  buy him an ice. It'll kill twenty  minutes.

dialogues.text: I've got a lot more than twenty  minutes to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough... (checking his watch) ...I get off duty at five-thirty. (bored, anxious to  make conversation) How long you been divorced?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Three months. How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got that look. My lady and I  split two years ago in August and  I'm an old pro at this shit. First  thing, stay away from the Children's  Zoo. It's pure hell В– if I never see  another chicken, I'll be happy. (calling out to his  daughter OFF SCREEN) I'm here, darling. Don't worry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finding this distinctly unpleasant. He glances around, lo for Billy.

dialogues.text: The sprinkler area. Other children are running around, bu there is no sign of Billy.

dialogues.text: As he grabs his stuff and starts toward the exit of the  playground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking in another direction. Nothing.

dialogues.text: Standing among a crowd of people just outside the entranc to the playground. He is looking around wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?!

dialogues.text: There in the distance is Billy Kramer, running as hard as can away from Ted.

dialogues.text: TRACKING IN FRONT OF HIM as he starts to chase after Bill

dialogues.text: It is clear that Billy is running with a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catching up to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later he gets close enough to grab onto her skir As the woman turns around:

dialogues.text: His face reveals all of the pain that Billy's can't.

dialogues.text: Across the room eighteen to twenty mothers (Ted Kramer is the only man present) are gathered, sitting on tiny chair and at work tables watching as their children put on a sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen...

dialogues.text: Welcome to the greatest show on earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the... (he forgets again)

dialogues.text: He leans forward mouthing the words as the teacher prompt Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greatest.

dialogues.text: Greatest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On earth.

dialogues.text: Ted breathes a sigh of relief, his son having gotten thro it.

dialogues.text: A look of total pleasure on his face. From time to time w Billy does something particularly difficult, Ted nudges t woman next to him. dialogues.text: The show is over and the parents and children mill around eating popcorn, drinking lemonade from paper cups. Ted st off to one side, talking to the teacher as Billy runs aro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, I just wanted to tell  you what a wonderful boy your son  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly attracted to  her) I don't know... I've been worried... (glancing around,  making sure Billy is  out of earshot) I mean, with what he's been through  and everything. I В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solicitously) No... No... Billy is doing just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving himself a few  points) Well, you know it's not easy raising  a kid on your own and I thought if  we could get together and, uh, discuss  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment one of the class mothers interrupts, reach across Ted and takes hold of the teacher's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (effusive) Barbara! Congratulations! When is  the baby due?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Not 'til August.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Inadvertently glancing at the teacher's stomach, nothing  shows.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TEACHER
dialogues.text: As she turns back to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You said you wanted to  talk, Mr. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Yes, but... ah, not now... (checking his watch) I've got an appointment... I forgot  all about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted begins beating a hasty retreat,

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: TRACKING IN FRONT OF HIM as he walks down the street carr a large and elaborate papier-mГўchГ© art thing that Billy in school.

dialogues.text: As he manages to notice every single pretty girl that pas thread his way through the crowd and still balance Billy' enormous work of art.

dialogues.text: As they open, Ted squeezes off and AS THE CAMERA TRACKS W HIM, he crosses the waiting room and enters the offices  proper. She jumps up from her desk, takes t papier-mГўchГ© thing and her notebook in hand, and follow as he walks down the corridor towards O'Connor's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Connor called. There's a meeting  with the Revlon people in the board  room and you're fifteen minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a rush) I know... I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schmidt can't have the figures  on the television buy until Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Uh, uh. Tell him I asked for it  Friday. I want it Friday. Period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lombardo from packaging wants to  meet on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have reached the board room. He enters withou knocking, his secretary still in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mrs. Kelsey called to ask if  Billy can come to Stephanie's birthday  party on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with executives in three piece suits a O'Connor who is doing a lot of backing and filling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he enters) Yes. Remind me to pick up a "Crying  Chrissie" doll at lunch on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: ON O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Clearly he is very irritated at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic) If it's all right with you, Mother  Kramer, can we get down to work now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a real mess, legal files and law books scattered  everywhere. In the midst of all this chaos sits PHYLLIS BERNARD, as w said before, she is about thirty, very pretty in spite of her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: She looks up as Ted enters. It is clear from their attitu that they have known one another for a long time and are  very relaxed together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He drops into a chair and shoves a stack of papers across the desk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Phyllis. These are the Revlon  contracts. I thought you ought to  check them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the papers and starts to rifle through them,  stopping every so often and making a note in the margin. she does, we notice that the second and third buttons of blouse have come undone and that she is not wearing a bra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he realizes this.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: She glances up to ask Ted a question about some point or  other, notices the direction of his gaze and, unself- consciously buttons up her blouse. She goes back to her papers as Ted continues to watch her

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: Not looking up from her papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baffled) Yes, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up, serious) Yes, I'll have dinner with you.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BED
dialogues.text: Although the room is dimly lit, we can SEE quite clearly  that Ted and Phyllis are in bed together. They have finis making love and Ted lies back, half asleep. Phyllis reach across to the nightstand, puts on her glasses and checks watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kramer, I've got to go. I've got an  eight o'clock closing tomorrow down  on Centre Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half asleep) Mmmmnph... I'll get you a cab...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he makes no move to get up. Phyllis gets to her feet and in the dim light we can SEE  that, except for her glasses, she is naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she crosses the  hall on the way to  the bathroom) That's okay. It's just that I've got  these clients that are В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is Billy Kramer, standing by the toilet, buttoning pajamas. He looks up at Phyllis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There stands Phyllis, naked as the day she was born, a lo of stunned amazement on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly to herself) Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too startled to cover herself.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: He looks her up and down, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very serious) Do you like fried chicken?

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: Suddenly remembering to cover herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoping desperately  it is the right answer) Ah... Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he shuffles off to bed. Phyllis waits, frozen until h disappears into his room. Then, she turns and flees back  into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: As she bursts into the room, closes the door behind her,  leans against it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes wide) I just met your son.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Who has leapt out of bed and is scrambling into his pants

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to know if I liked fried  chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods rather frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) So what's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND THELMA
dialogues.text: Stand side by side. He is cutting, chopping, making some  kind of stew. Thelma stands nearby watching, sipping a gl of white wine. FROM OFF SCREEN we can hear Billy and Kim running around, playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever think about getting married  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really... (she thinks for a  moment, then:) I guess it's different if you don't  have children, but... I dunno, even  if Charley and I don't live together,  even if we're sleeping with other  people, even if Charley was to marry  again... He'd still be my husband.  That stuff about "Till death do you  part?" That's really true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding toward a  cookbook that is  propped open nearby) How many onions does it say to use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without bothering to  look in the book) Three. And add some basil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he does) D'you think you and Charley'll ever  get back together again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Thel. So Charley had a little  fling. So what? All in all he was a  pretty good husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know this isn't gonna make  any sense, okay? I mean forget the  logic part... But I keep thinking if  Charley really loved me, he wouldn't  have let me divorce him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Saturday Father and his daughter, clearly with nothin to say to one another, stand eating ices from a nearby ve THE CAMERA PANS AWAY FROM THEM across to Billy, Ted and  Phyllis. She is dressed in a very nice suit, silk blouse, high heeled shoes and looks distinctly out of place in Ce Park on a Saturday afternoon. At the moment, Ted is trying to teach Billy how to bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, you hold it like this... (he places Billy's  hands on the bat  just so) ...and you swing like this... (taking him through  the motions)

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: Watching. She can't believe what she's seeing. Finally, s can't stand it any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) No, no, no, Kramer. That's not how  you do it. Look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to Billy, gently takes the bat from him and  demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you hold it like this... (showing him her grip) Farther down the bat. And you swing  like this... (to Ted) Throw me one.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he gives Billy a look that says, we have to humor her. throws a ball.

dialogues.speaker: ON PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: As she swings, connects and slams a ball in a long, loopi fly that goes at least two hundred feet.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Watching the ball disappear in the distance, he turns bac to Phyllis, open-mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, she grins, shrugs and hands the bat back to  Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connor, Murray and the Art Director are in O'Connor's o as the door opens and Ted enters, carrying a pile of pape charts, graphs, etc., etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Jim. Here's the report on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops in mid-sentence, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the walls are a series of mock-ups of the various Fire and Ice ads, none of which are what Ted and O'Connor had  agreed upon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocent) Murray had some ideas about the Fire  and Ice campaign and he had the art  department make up a few roughs... (weakly) I think they're kind of interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bugged) I don't. Jim, this isn't anything  like what we talked about. It's not  even close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oily) Ted, basically it's still your  concept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chiming in) Murray just added a few things, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold it right there, I'm the one  that went in and sold Revlon on this  idea to start with, remember? You  said I was going to be В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound-effect: The phone rings. O'Connor picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens for a moment, then hands the phone to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for you.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he takes the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, embarrassed, he turns his back and lowers his voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Billy, I told you before, one  hour of T.V. a day, that's the rule...  No... (clearly, Billy is  giving him an argument) I don't care what the other mothers  do... Listen, I can't talk now, I'm  in a meeting... (firm) Billy, I'll talk to you later, good- bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: During the phone call, the CAMERA PANS AWAY to Murr & O'connor, looks of bored Condescension and smug sup on their faces. Ted hangs up the phone and turns back around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smooth) Ted, I appreciate what you're saying,  but I really think you're just too  close to it right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Murray's right. (reassuring) Look it's just some ideas, okay? I  mean nothing's locked in cement. I  promise you this is your show...

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Not very reassured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me on this one, Ted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is sitting at the dining room table, working. Spread all across the table are layouts, rate sheets, etc., etc. Billy sits across from him drawing on a pad with felt-tip pens. HOLD FOR A BEAT, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried about  something) Mom, I mean dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy) In a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beat of silence then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do when an elephant sits  on your fence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get a new fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he hasn't heard a  word) C'mon, Billy. I'm trying to work for  God's sake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another beat of silence, then Billy reaches for his glass Hawaiian Punch and accidentally tips it over, spilling pu liquid across all of Ted's papers. Instantly, Ted is on his feet, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, can't you watch what you're  doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je-sus Christ! I catch all kind of  shit at the office because I'm not  pulling my weight because I'm busting  my butt trying to be a decent goddamn  father and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic) That's terrific. That's really  terrific, but I notice I'm the one  that's cleaning up this В– (noticing an important  paper covered with  grape juice) Oh, crap, I'll have to do this one  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to help) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now there is nothing the boy can do right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's after your bedtime, okay?  Just do me a favor and go to bed,  okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy gets to his feet, collects his stuff and walks into his bedroom. HOLD ON TED who sits for a moment, then gets wearily to his feet and as THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM cro to the door of Billy's room. He stops in the doorway, loo OFF SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy struggling to get his pajamas on, having a hard tim

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry I yelled, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just... I've been catching a  lot of flack at the office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR TO O'CONNOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: As it opens and Phyllis comes out. In the background in  O'Connor's office we SEE O'Connor and Murray, talking,  laughing. THE CAMERA TRACKS ALONGSIDE Phyllis as she walks to Ted  Kramer's office and opens the door without knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about lunch, Kramer. I'm buying.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND PHYLLIS
dialogues.text: As they sit across from one another. A waiter stands over them, setting drinks in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perrier and lime... (placing a drink in  front of Phyllis) ...and scotch with soda. (putting Ted's drink  in front of him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter bustles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Phyllis, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kramer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks off, uncertain whether or not to go on. Then,  making up her mind, she reaches across, takes Ted's scotc and soda and drinks half of it down in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a rush) O'Connor's out to get you. He's going  to take the Fire and Ice account  away from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) What?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) I don't believe it! That's crazy!  Why would Jim do something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phyllis polishes off the rest of Ted's drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry herself) You want to know why? I'll tell you  why... (signaling to the  waiter) Another scotch and soda for the  gentleman. (back to Ted) I'll tell you exactly why. Because  you're not his buddy anymore. Because  he can't count on you to sit around  the office every night until eight  or nine and shoot the shit with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I've got Billy to take care  of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) You dope. O'Connor doesn't give a  damn about Billy. All he wants is  somebody that'll hang around with  him every night so he won't have to  go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff) I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter sets Ted's drink on the table in front of him. starts to reach for it, but Phyllis is quicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a stiff drink) All right. Okay. But tell me  something, Kramer. Who do you think  is palling around with O'Connor these  days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION, TED
dialogues.text: Stunned, but trying to be nonchalant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what's so terrible about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (would like to take  him by the shoulders  and shake him until  his teeth rattle) Oh, for God's sake, Kramer. You have  got to be the world's most naive  human being. (leaning forward) Murray has gone in and changed every  single ad you've done on the entire  Fire and Ice campaign. Every layout...  Every idea... Every single thing,  right down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I don't believe it. Jim  O'Connor would never let anything  like that happen. He gave me my shot  in this business. If it wasn't for  Jim O'Connor I'd be В– I don't know  where I'd be. He's a wonderful man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic for having  upset Ted) Kramer, I'm sorry. All I was trying  to do was В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) I don't want to hear another word  against him. Not another word. He's  a wonderful man... a wonderful man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: The finished proof of the ad that Murray had done that Ted had seen in O'Connor's office.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH HIM as he steams out of his door and marche along the corridor to O'Connor's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Ted brushes past  her) I'm sorry, Mr. O'Connor is in  conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is too late. Ted barrels into O'Connor's office wi bothering to knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connor is alone in the office. He looks up startled as comes barging in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) All right, Jim. You said I was running  this show, right? You said no  decisions without my approval, right? (brandishing the ad) Well what the hell is this? What's  going on, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Well, ah... I thought it over and I  decided we're doing it Murray's way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, this is garbage. This isn't  anything like what we talked to Revlon  about. None of it. You can't В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tough) That's my decision, Ted and that's  final.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Who sits looking down at the plate of food in front of hi as though it was a coiled rattlesnake about to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Preoccupied, jumpy. He is eating, but he doesn't taste a  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salisbury steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't hate it. We had Salisbury  steak last week and you liked it  fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubborn) No I didn't. I hate the brown stuff.  It's gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strained patience) All it is is onions and gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm allergic to onions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not allergic of onions. You've  had them lots of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen) I want a pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying not to lose  patience) No. This is fine. Just take a bite,  you'll like it fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
