dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Billy takes a tiny bite. He barely puts it i his mouth before he spits it out with a great show of bei physically ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to throw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting pissed off) Oh, for God's sake... Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches across and scrapes most of the sauce off of th meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, okay? Now that's just plain  old hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the brown stuff is still  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through clenched  teeth) Then eat around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anger building) Now listen to me, young man. Do you  know what I had to go through to put  this goddamn food on the goddamn  table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obstinate) I don't care. I hate it. I want pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing up) Not on your life. That's it. I've  had it with crap around this house.  From now on, no more pizza! Get it?  Starting right now you can eat real  food like a normal human being!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now both of them are out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know something?! You are  a spoiled selfish little brat! Now  eat В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy takes his plate and looking his father straight in eye deliberately overturns it, spilling food everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He is out of his chair like a shot, crosses to Billy and  jerks him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Goddamnit! Go to your room!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He half-carries, half-drags the child kicking and screami into his room. THE CAMERA TRACKS ALONGSIDE THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the top of his  voice) Owwww... You're hurting me... You're  hurting me... I hate you... I hate  you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seething) You're no bargain either, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want my mommy... I want my mommy..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now they have reached Billy's room. Ted dumps him on t bed unceremoniously and starts out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I want my... mm... ommy... I want  mmmy... mommy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) Tough shit. You're stuck with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he slams the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dining area. Ted sits down and tries to resume his me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing, fighting to  catch his breath) I want my... mmmo... mmmy. I want  mmmy mmo... mmy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he lifts his glass to take a drink and we can SEE that is shaking like a leaf.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he finishes doing the last of the dishes, dries his ha and looks around to make sure that everything has been pu away. He flips off the light and, as THE CAMERA TRACKS WI HIM, he walks from room to room, turning off the lights,  until he reaches the door to Billy's room which is still  closed. Ted hesitates for a moment, then eases open the d and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy lies sprawled across the bed, all tangled up in the covers.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he crosses to the sleeping child and starts to straigh the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all anger gone) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kisses him) That's okay, pal. Go back to sleep.  It's very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get up, when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quiet) Are you... gonna go... away?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Stunned at the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm not going away. I love  you very much. I'll be right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it comes pouring out) That's why mommy left... isn't it?  'Cause I was bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy begins to weep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he puts his arm around  Billy and holds him  close) Oh, Christ... Oh, Christ... (he thinks for a  moment, then:) No, pal. Your mom loves you very  much. The reason she left didn't  have anything to do with you. (pause, this is very  painful) Look, I don't know if this will make  any sense to you, okay? But I'll try  and explain. You see the reason your  mom left was because... Well, I guess  it was because I kept trying to make  her into a certain kind of person...  Make her be the way I thought a wife  was supposed to be. Only she wasn't  like that. She was... (smiles to himself) Well, she wasn't like that. And now,  when I think about it, I can see she  tried very hard to be like I wanted  В– very hard. And when she couldn't,  then she tried to tell me about it.  Only I wouldn't listen. I guess I  thought that if I was happy, that  meant she was happy too. Only she  wasn't. The truth is, the only reason  she didn't leave a lot sooner was  because she loves you so much. Joanna  stayed until she couldn't stand me  any longer and then she left... But  it wasn't you, pal. It wasn't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long beat of silence as Billy thinks about thi Clearly an enormous burden has been lifted from his shoul Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is mom ever coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean for good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted gets to his feet, starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go to sleep. It's very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let the bedbugs bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted pauses in the doorway, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted runs along beside Billy, who is learning to ride a bike. Then, in the last shot, Ted lets go of the bike and runs  along just behind. Slowly as Billy gains confidence he sp up, leaving Ted farther and farther behind. Finally, as B glances over his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the boy, by now a considerable distance away, turns an waves.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Waving back, a grin of enormous pride on his face. He gla around, embarrassed to make sure no one is watching and w tears from his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ON A BUS
dialogues.text: As it pulls to a stop and a mob of mothers and children g off. Among them we spot Billy and Ted Kramer. THE CAMERA PANS  WITH THEM as they cross the street and enter the school  building. THE CAMERA CONTINUES IT'S PAN across the street to a Coffee Shop with large plate glass windows facing th school. There, standing in the window, watching, is Joann Kramer. HOLD AS THE CAMERA SLOWLY ZOOMS IN ON HER and we a look of overwhelming pain on her face.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND THELMA
dialogues.text: Sitting on a bench, the area around them is stacked high  with toys that the kids have brought with them to the par OFF SCREEN we can HEAR Billy and Kim racing around, playi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little too casual) Thel, you ever hear from Joanna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also with deliberate  nonchalance) Not for a couple of months. The last  time I heard from her she was living  in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) California?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him) Uh, huh... She said she had a good  job, was playing a lot of tennis.  She wanted to know all about Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the real question) She ever ask about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) Uh, huh... Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her you're doing a pretty  good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy! Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted glances around:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Kim are standing near the jungle Jim. Billy has toy airplane in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, look! Presenting Billy Kramer's  Fantastic Superjet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he begins to race around the area, making jet noises holding the airplane in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON TED
dialogues.text: Watching him, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Weaving in and around the benches. He turns and starts ba towards Ted. As he does:

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT
dialogues.text: Billy's foot, as he trips.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he starts to fall, still holding onto the airplane.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT
dialogues.text: Watching, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he hits the concrete.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He leaps to his feet, starts toward the boy.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a terrible-looking gash running from his cheek i his hairline. Kim screams at the sight of the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: As Ted, carrying Billy, wrapped in his coat, comes barrel out of the park, nearly knocking over several people with shopping bags, and begins running like hell WITH THE CAME TRACKING JUST IN FRONT OF HIM. In the BACKGROUND we SEE T and Kim chasing after him. THE LENGTH OF THE TRACKING SHO

dialogues.speaker: ON TED KRAMER
dialogues.text: He is covered with Billy's blood, it is on his face, his  shirt, his trousers. At the moment 'he stands helpless,  watching as, Off-Screen, a surgeon examines Billy's wound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm, reassuring) That's good, Billy... That's a brave  boy... Now then, how's that? Now  we've cleaned it out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy lies on the examining table with the doctor bending over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. That wasn't so bad, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, you just wait here, Billy.  I want to talk to your dad for a  minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor motions for Thelma to wait with Billy and he  crosses to Ted who stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low voice, again  calm and reassuring) Your boy is very lucky, Mr. Kramer.  One inch over and it would have caught  the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm going to have to take some  stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flat) How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted closes his eyes, there is a sharp intake of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the position of the wound  and your son's age, I don't think  there will be much of a scar.  Otherwise I'd call in a plastic  surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'd advise you to wait outside.  It'll be eas В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a shot) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reasonable) Mr. Kramer, there's В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, but with  real vehemence) Fuck you. He's my son. I'm staying  with him.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He holds his son tightly while the doctor stitches up the boy's wound. From THIS CAMERA ANGLE we can SEE Ted's face but only the back of Billy's head. Although we do not see the stitches being made, we do SEE the doctor's hand, wit the needle and surgical thread as it moves into and out o view with a slow, steady rhythm. Billy's hand clutches Te so tightly that the knuckles are white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, as each stitch  is taken) Ohhh... Ohhhh... Ohhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to his  child) It's okay, son... I'm here... Just a  little more to go... Don't worry,  son... I'm here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is late, only a few lights are still on.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: He lies in bed, fast asleep, his head swathed in bandages THE CAMERA PANS AWAY FROM HIM across to Ted, who sits in nearby rocking chair, watching his son. HOLD FOR A BEAT,  then Ted gets to his feet, walks quietly to the door and  steps out into the hall, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma having washed and dried the dishes is now wiping o the top of the counter top, more to keep busy than anythi else. She looks around as Ted enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is he?

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON TED
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway. He hasn't changed his clothes an he is still covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) He's okay... Thel, can I ask you a  favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean a little favor. I mean  a big F favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma nods. She watches Ted closely. He doesn't look at  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma, if I die В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aghast) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I didn't say I'm going to die, but  if I should В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply upset) Don't say that! I don't want to hear  you say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Thel, listen to me. If, on the million  to one shot that I should В– (correcting himself) That anything should happen to me.  Would you take care of Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) Me?! You want me to take care of  Billy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought about it a lot and you're  the only person I know that I trust  with him. I mean, if anything happened  to me, he'd be okay with you. You're  a good mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Thelma looks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily) I know it's not an easy thing to  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. She still cannot look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if it's too much responsibility  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma nods, unable to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Thel. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: As he lies in bed asleep. Some time has passed and Billy' bandage is much smaller. HOLD ON HIM as we HEAR OFF SCREE Sound: From the street below, the regular six-forty-five  garbage truck that serves as Billy's alarm clock.

dialogues.speaker: HOLD ON BILLY
dialogues.text: As he wakes up, struggles to his feet. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM as, eyes closed, he stumbles i the bathroom, pees, and still not remembering to flush th toilet walks into the bedroom and wakes his father. As th child turns and walks toward the kitchen, THE CAMERA HOLD ON TED. He heaves himself to his feet and, eyes closed, i much the same manner as his son, stumbles into the bathro He automatically flushes the toilet without bothering to  look, walks into the living room, opens the front door an picks up the paper. As he starts into the kitchen, he mee Billy coming the other way carrying two plates, a doughnu on each. THE CAMERA NOW TRACKS WITH BILLY as he walks into the liv room, carefully sets the plates on the dining table, cros to the television set, and turns it on. He returns to the table, and sits down as Ted appears carrying two glasses orange juice and vitamins. He takes a seat in the chair  opposite Billy and opens his paper and starts to read. HOLD ON THEM as they sit without talking, eating their  breakfast В– the only sound, a children's cartoon program coming from the T.V. From time to time Ted glances up from his paper to look a at the cartoon. HOLD ON THEM as we SEE that they have become roommates in the best sense of the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a gray, cloudy day in mid-November. Snow is falling Sound-effect: a telephone ringing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As Ted enters, looks around. The Maitre d'hotel approache From his attitude, it is clear that Ted and Joanna were  regular customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Kramer. We haven't  seen you for a long time. Mrs. Kramer,  she waits for you in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH TED as he walks toward the back ro of the restaurant. Several waiters approach and say hello the piano player looks up and smiles. As he reaches the d to the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits against the wall, a glass of white wine in front her. She is dressed simply and no longer has a tan. Neverthele Joanna is still stunningly beautiful. HOLD ON HER FOR A B as she looks up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He stands watching her, his knees weak. It is impossible to fall in love with her all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he crosses to her table, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Ted. You look well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter appears, carrying a scotch and soda. He sets i down on the table in front of Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual, Mr. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not taking his eyes  off Joanna) Thanks, Gino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter nods and promptly disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the new job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a self-conscious pause. From the bar, the piano  player begins playing a new song. From Ted and Joanna's  reaction, it is clearly a song that has meant a great dea to them in the past. They listen for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at us, Joanna. Just like any  old married couple having dinner.  Who would believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... How's Billy?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: The question he has been dreading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's great... except... (not looking at her) ...Except he had... he fell and he  cut his face. He... He has a scar,  Joanna, from about here to here. (indicating where and  how big)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence. A moment of shared feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has to say it to  someone) I can't help but feel somehow...  it's my fault. I keep thinking I  could've done something В– stopped  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't tell it from a distance,  Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time he looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few times. Sometimes I sit in that  coffee shop across the street and  watch when you take him to school.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like a terrific kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is... (he still can't get  over it) You sat in that coffee shop across  from school В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completing the  sentence) Watching my son... Ted, I've been  living in New York for the past two  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) You've been living here, in the city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep breath) Ted... The reason I wanted to see  you... I want Billy back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm) I want my son. I'm through sitting  in coffee shops looking at him from  across the street. I want my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?! You're  the one that walked out on him,  remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to explain) Ted, listen to me... You and I, we  had a really crappy marriage В– (hastily) Look, don't get so defensive, okay?  It was probably as much my fault as  it was yours... Anyway when I left I  was really screwed up В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna, I don't give a В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she will be heard) Ted, all my life I'd either been  somebody's daughter or somebody's  wife, or somebody else's mother.  Then all of a sudden, I was a thirty- two-year-old, highly neurotic woman  who had just walked out on her husband  and child. I went to California  because that was about as far away  as I could get. Only... I guess it  wasn't far enough. So I started going  to a shrink. (leaning forward,  very sincere) Ted, I've had time to think. I've  been through some changes. I've  learned a lot about myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a shot) Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boring in) Come on, Joanna, what did you learn?  I'd really like to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relentless) One thing, okay? Just tell me one  goddam thing you've learned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, determined) I've learned that I want my son.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He reacts as though he has been slapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna, go be a mother. Get married,  have kids. Don't get married, have  kids. Do whatever you want. I don't  give a damn. Just leave me out of it  В– and leave my baby out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, if you can't discuss this  rationally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to his feet) Joanna, go fuck yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that he turns on his heels and stalks out of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, very plush office: lots of antiques, beautiful  nineteenth century paintings on the wall along with  autographed photographs of at least three ex-Presidents o the United States. Sitting behind a large and imposing de is JOHN SHAUNESSY, a handsome, formidable man in his earl sixties. He is well-dressed, a cornflower in his buttonho that sort of thing. At the moment, Shaunessy leans back i his chair as Ted finishes his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward,  intense) Look, she walked out on her own child,  right? That's desertion, right? Mr.  Shaunessy, I'm telling you it's an  open and shut case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, there's no such thing as an  open and shut case. Especially where  custody is involved. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second, the burden is on us to prove  your ex-wife is an unfit mother.  That means I'm going to have to play  rough and, if I play rough, you can  bet they will too. Can you take that,  Mr. Kramer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third, it'll cost you five thousand  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION TED
dialogues.text: That's an astronomical amount of money to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's if we win. If we lose, you  could end up having to pay your wife's  court costs as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determined) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You've hired yourself a hell  of a lawyer, Mr. Kramer. (down to business) How old is the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHAUNESSY
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's tough. In most cases involving  a child that young, the court tends  to side with the mother.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Agitated. This is not what he wanted to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she signed over custody. Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs in his pockets, pulls out a piece of paper and th it at the lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at it) I'm not saying we don't have a shot,  but it won't be easy... (thinks for a moment) Mr. Kramer, do me a favor. There is  something I find very helpful in  matters like this. I sit down and  make a list of all the pros and cons  on an issue. I actually write them  down and look at them. I want you to  do that, okay? Then, after that, if  you're really sure you want to retain  custody of your child В– then we'll  go in there and whip their asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits at the dining table, the supper dishes have been pushed aside. He has a legal pad in front of him and is  writing. THE CAMERA DOLLIES IN CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The legal pad. On one side Ted has written "Pro" and on t other, "Con." Underneath "Con" Ted has written a long lis of the drawbacks involved in keeping Billy: Sex Life, Mon Possibility of Remarriage, Sleep, Emotional Dependence. T "Pro" side of the list is empty.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He sits for a moment, staring at the list, then he crumpl the paper, gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As Ted enters. He crosses to Billy's bed where the child fast asleep, sits down on the edge, and starts to rub the child's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you Billy Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-asleep) I love you too daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted kisses the child, gets to his feet and starts toward door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep tight. Don't let the bedbugs  bite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost asleep again) See you in the morning light...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O'Connor stands with his back to Ted, looking out the win From the beginning this is clearly an awkward and unpleas moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared to do what he  is about to do) Look, ah... Ted. I just got word  from the guys at Revlon and... ah  they did some marketing tests on our  campaign and the results were...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Hold on him listening as it slowly dawns on him that he i being fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff) Disappointing. It only pulled a  fourteen share and they were hoping  for a twenty five minimum, and...  ah... they're not very happy and...  Well, the guys have decided they  want to... ah, re-think the entire  concept and... Look, I don't like  having to do this, okay?... But... I  mean, what I mean is... ah, I'm going  to have to... ah, let you go В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not really sure he  heard right) Are you firing me, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: ON O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: He still has his back to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Ted, don't get emotional.  Okay? (whining) Look, this isn't exactly an easy  thing for me to do, y'know? I swear  Murray and I did everything we could,  but those sons of bitches were out  for blood. I mean it was all I could  do to keep the account inside the  shop... Look, I promise, if I hear  of anything I'll let you know first  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I want В– O'Connor looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty, the door stands open and Ted is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted grabs a picture of Billy from his desk, takes his  jacket and coat and stalks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALONGSIDE TED
dialogues.text: As he walks along the street in a state of total shock. B him, in the windows of expensive stores we note Christmas decorations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits across from the interviewer, a polished young ma in his middle twenties, very efficient, he sounds a bit l a tape recording.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at a form  Ted has filled out) Ummm, hmmm... umm, hmmm... (the good news) Well, this looks very good.. Of course (the bad news) ...you understand this is the worst  time of the year to look for a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic) What?! What do you mean, I don't  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patronizing) Mr. Kramer, nobody even thinks about  leaving their job until after they  get their Christmas bonus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you don't understand. I need a  job. I've got a kid and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smooth) I understand and I'm absolutely sure  something wonderful will turn up... (ending any further  discussion) ...after the first of the year.

dialogues.speaker: ON A TELEPHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Ted stands inside, talking on the phone. AS THE CAMERA DO IN CLOSER, he hangs up the receiver and takes the employm section of the New York Times which is filled with listin he has circled and crosses off one. He goes on to the nex takes a dime from the stack on the shelf in front of him starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Who stands at the sink doing the last of the dishes. A  dishtowel is tucked into his belt, serving as an apron. H ON HIM as we HEAR: Sound-effect: The phone ringing. Ted wipes his hands, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the phone) Mr. Kramer? Please hold for Mr.  Shaunessy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, a moment later:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted? They've set the court date. I  just heard today... It's... (checking his notes) January sixth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despair) Oh, Christ.. .John, there's some-  thing I ought to tell you. My... ah,  situation has... changed. I lost my  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause, too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Ted, I won't lie to you, we don't  have a hope in hell of winning a  custody hearing if you're out of  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted doubles over the phone like he has been hit in the  stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, but with  real feeling) Good Christ, Joanna, just get the  hell out of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted? Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any prospects?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make himself  believe it) Don't worry. I plan to have something  within twenty-four hours, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) How the hell are you going to do  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same young man sits across the desk from Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirk) Mis-ter Kramer, as I mentioned  yesterday, this is a very bad time  of year to look for work. Now I'm  sure we'll have something for you by  mid-February, March at the latest.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Leaning forward, impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a job, now.

dialogues.speaker: CROSS-CUTTING BETWEEN THEM
dialogues.text: The interviewer gives Ted a weary look. Then he starts to flip through the card file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going through the  motions) No... No... No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally he pauses at one card, pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) There might be something at J. Walter  Thompson. But... (shaking his head) ...I don't think they're really  serious. The position's been open  for two months and... (shrugs) They may just be on a fishing  expedition. (cheerful) I'm sure you'll be much happier if  you wait until after the first В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Call up the people at J. Walter  Thompson. Set up an appointment at  four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politeness strained  almost to the breaking  point) Mis-ter Kramer, it's... (checking his watch) ...almost four now. It's the Friday  before Christmas. Nobody is going to  want to В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward,  tough as nails) Either you call and set up the  appointment, or I'll call. And if I  call, you lose the commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arch) My, we are a hot shot aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is already on his feet and halfway out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your ass.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: It is dark outside and the lights are on in the office. F beyond the door, we can hear the sounds of a Christmas of party in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: ON JACK ACKERMAN
dialogues.text: The advertising manager. A balding man in his mid-forties he wears a suit, complete with vest. At the moment he sit behind his desk listening to Ted's spiel, from time to ti he glances at the resume on the desk in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Ackerman, as you can see  from my resume, my experience in  setting up the leisure package concept  means that I've spent a lot of time  working along the same lines as your  multiple buys and your regional  advertising ideas. I know the  pitfalls, but В– and this is more  important В– I know the potential  revenue for the company inherent in  these programs.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he finishes. He sits back, pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Kramer, I must say this  has been very impressive. I'd like  to think about it and get back to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) Mr. Ackerman, is there anyone else  that I should see before you come to  a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Spencer, our Advertising Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no time to waste) Could I see him right away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I'm sorry, but he's leaving this  evening for a two-week vacation.  I'll set up something the moment he  gets back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, starts to shake Ted's hand, ready to end the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see him now В– before he  leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, I don't think В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (means it) I want this position very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ackerman gives Ted a long, considered look, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large room is crowded with secretaries, junior execut researchers, editors, ad-men, etc., etc. They all have dr in their hands and there is a good deal of kissing and ge conviviality going on. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH ACKERMAN as he steps out of his of closes the door behind him and makes his way across the r to MR. SPENCER, the Advertising Director. At the moment,  Spencer stands with his coat over one arm and a drink in hand talking to a very pretty young woman. Ackerman appro him, whispers something in his ear. Spencer shakes his he and points to his watch. Ackerman says something else and finally, with a look of weary resignation, Spencer excuse himself from the pretty young woman and follows Ackerman  back to his office. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM. As Ackerman  opens the door to his office, THE CAMERA IS ANGLED so tha we can SEE past them, into the office where Ted stands  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they enter) Mr. Spencer, Mr. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wasting any time) So you're the go-getter. All right,  you've got ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door closes behind them, blocking our view, THE CA PANS UP to a clock over the door. It reads five-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: ON A CLOCK
dialogues.text: Which now reads five twenty-two. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL Spencer, now sitting in Ackerman's chair, his feet Ackerman's desk. Ted has just finished his pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping his drink) That's very interesting, Mr. Kramer.  I must say, it's very interesting.  Let me think about it. I'll let  Jack... (indicating Ackerman) ...know and he'll get in touch with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer gets to his feet, starts to retrieve his coat.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he decides to take a gamble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I believe you said I had  ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ON SPENCER
dialogues.text: Almost at the door, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Checking his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means I've got two minutes left.  I understand you're paying twenty- five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep breath, then  a real huckster) All right, I'll tell you what I'm  gonna do В– I'll take the job at twenty- two-five. Now, that's twenty-five  hundred less than you're offering.  The only thing is, you have to say  yes right now. Not tomorrow. Not  next week. Not after the holidays.  It's worth it to me for a yes right  now and I'll take twenty-five hundred  less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long beat of silence as Spencer and Ackerman l at one another. They were clearly not prepared for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching them) Today only. One day only. Twenty-two  five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, can we talk privately  for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he steps out of Ackerman's office, sits down. Now, all the fear, all of the anxiety that he has been fighting do comes welling up. What if he pushed too hard? What will h do if he doesn't get a job? If Ted Kramer could fall to h knees and pray, he would.

dialogues.speaker: CROSS-CUT WITH THE CHRISTMAS PARTY
dialogues.text: That swirls around him. We notice in particular, one very pretty young woman flirting with a number of men. She is  wearing a dress with straps, one of them has broken and s has patched it with a piece of masking tape. Finally the door to Ackerman's office opens and he steps  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted jumps to his feet, starts into the office.

dialogues.speaker: ON SPENCER
dialogues.text: He looks at Ted carefully for a long time, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Welcome aboard, Mr. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an instant of relief, then, with astounding cool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, I'm pleased to be  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they shake hands, say their good-byes. THE CAMERA TRAC WITH TED as he makes his way through the Christmas party  that is still going strong. Then, suddenly, as he passes very pretty woman we noticed earlier, he turns and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a look passes between them, a sudden chemistry, someth we have not seen in Ted before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps back from the  astounded girl, grins) Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: ON A BUS
dialogues.text: As it pulls to a stop, the doors open and, along with the usual flood of mothers and children we SEE Ted and Billy. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH THEM as they walk to school. Billy talking a mile a minute, describing in minute detail the  plot of an episode of "I Dream of Jeannie." Ted listens  intently, then, almost involuntarily, he glances over his shoulder in the direction of the Coffee Shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, standing in the window, watching, is Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND BILLY
dialogues.text: As they continue to walk. Ted's eyes remain on Joanna. As they reach the door to the school, Ted looks at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing Billy goodbye) You're a terrific kid, Billy Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands watching as Billy rushes off into the building. Then he turns back and once again looks in the direction the Coffee Shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time there is no one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD FOR A BEAT as we HEAR: OFF SCREEN Sound: A telephone ringing. Then, a moment lat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted? John Shaunessy here. I just got  a call from your wife's lawyer. She  wants to see the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted Kramer, the phone cradled against his ear is cleaning the remains of one of Billy's attempts to make the perfec peanut butter sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! She wants what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's been through  this a million times) She's the mother. That means she's  within her legal rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated) John, what if she kidnaps him. I've  heard all these В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the patience of a  saint) Look, Ted, I don't honestly think  she would go to the trouble of suing  you for custody of the child if she  was planning on kidnapping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtful) I don't know, John... I mean, to be  brutally honest, I'm not so sure  what kind of mental shape Joanna's  in right now. Y'know she admitted  she was seeing a shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a flicker of interest) You ever see her talk to the walls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you don't have a choice. Have  Billy at the Seventy-Fifth Street  entrance to Central Park, Saturday  at ten.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND BILLY
dialogues.text: TRACKING IN FRONT OF THEM as they walk along the Central  Park side of Fifth Ave. From their attitude it is clear t each of them, for their own reasons, is very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About half a block away Joanna paces back and forth. She  hasn't seen them and it is clear that she is as nervous a they are.

dialogues.speaker: TED AND BILLY
dialogues.text: Ted stops, turns to Billy and gives him a last-minute che Then, spotting a smudge he takes his handkerchief, spits it and wipes the child's chin. Now satisfied, he takes Bi hand and they continue. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he spots his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT
dialogues.text: As she turns, spots Billy, starts to run.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: TRACKING WITH HIM as he lets go of Ted's hand and starts run flat out toward his mother. She kneels, opens her arm wide for him and he goes barreling into her, almost knock her down from the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhere between  laughter and tears) Oh, Billy... Oh my Billy... Oh my  son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna gets to her feet and takes Billy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted, but looking  at Billy) I'll have him back at six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they start off in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Realizing that Billy has not said good-bye, has not looke at him once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands helpless, watching them leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, now almost lost from view on the crowded street, sti hasn't moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Phyllis, getting ready to go to bed. They look li a couple that has been married at least five years. Ted i busy talking as he takes off his tie, jacket and starts t unbutton his shirt. Phyllis is getting undressed also, ha things in the closet, putting things away in drawers. But Ted continues to talk, she watches him apprehensively, it clear that something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he has become an  armchair lawyer) So, naturally, you assume that since  Joanna left, that would be a  compelling point against her, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't work that way. A major  decision was handed down by the  Appellate Court in 1969 В– in the  case of Haskins vs. Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kramer В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in Haskins vs. Haskins the court  ruled in favor of the mother, thus  establishing a precedent for awarding  the child to the mother even though  she previously abandoned the baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kramer... There's something I ought  to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been offered a job in Washington  with H.E.W.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He stops what he is doing, turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep breath) I'm going to take it.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: He sits down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very good job В– too good to  pass up. I'll be handling funding  for the whole... (she stops, sits beside  him on the bed) Look, I... (she means love) ..."like" you a lot. And you... (she means love) ..."like" me, okay? Maybe if it was  a year from now, maybe things would  be different...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet) But it's not a year from now, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head, then, reaches out and touches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll miss you, Kramer...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: It is open and standing in the doorway is an attractive w a bit overweight and very serious. This is DR. ALVAREZ, t court appointed psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dr. Alvarez, Judge Atkins asked  me to look in on your son and prepare  an evaluation sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Won't you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Alvarez enters the apartment. Ted helps her off with coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in his room, playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'll see him in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted carries her coat to the closet, Dr. Alvarez walks  into the living room, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, do you ever have sex in  here with anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, I attempt to conduct my social  life discreetly. At the moment I am  seeing no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that distress you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prospect of losing my child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes some notes,  then:) Very well, I'd like to see him if I  may.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross to the door of Billy's room. Ted opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is a mess, blocks are stacked everywhere. Billy  sits in the middle playing with his toys.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND DR. ALVAREZ
dialogues.text: They stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy. This is Dr. Alvarez. She would  like to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from his  toys) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an awkward pause as Ted remains in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly) I'd like to talk to Billy privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed at being  caught) Oh, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Ted leaves, closing the door behind him. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH HIM as he crosses the living room the couch where he has a stack of legal books and a numbe of note pads spread out. He is obviously continuing his l education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have here, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Detroit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I've been to Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you have people there. What  are their names?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Kim... and this one's Thelma  and that's Mrs. Willewska and this  is daddy and that's Batman and over  there is Robin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Here, this can be mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like to be with your mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted by now has given up all pretense of working. He wags pencil in the direction of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the defense attorney) Objection. You're leading the witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you like best about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch in a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you like best about your  daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, does your daddy ever hit  you?

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: Eyes wide. He starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Lots of times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This brings Ted all the way to his feet. He starts across the living room headed for the door to Billy's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) When does he hit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted has his hand on the doorknob, about to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits me on the planet Kriptarium,  when I steal the buried treasure  from the famous peanut butter factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In real life when does he hit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) My daddy doesn't hit me, silly. Why  would my daddy hit me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a Saturday afternoon. HOLD FOR A BEAT as we SEE Ted Kramer and Billy approaching. Billy is talking a mile a  minute. Ted listens intently, absorbed in the boy's  description. As they turn into the entrance of the office building:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long corridor with desks for secretaries lined up next doors leading to smaller individual offices. As they appr a door in the foreground that bears a small sign reading, "Ted Kramer":

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting Billy,  who is still in the  middle of his story) See. That's my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the sign) It's my name too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he opens the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a pleasant enough office, but nothing spectacular,  windows that look out over Fifty-seventh Street, simple  Formica furniture, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he stops dead in his  tracks at the sight  of the office) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy crosses to the window, presses his nose to the glas looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! Is this really where you work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted nods, walks over to the desk and begins collecting  paperwork to do over the weekend. As he does, Billy goes  through the office, sitting in every chair, looking in ev drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this really your desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that really your chair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! That's neat. Can I sit in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy plops himself down in Ted's chair, swivels around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did mommy ever see this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she never did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to get remarried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I hadn't thought much  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to remarried Phyllis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) No.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: There is a long pause, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you and mommy get remarried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stops what he is doing, looks across at Billy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, son. Daddy and mommy will never  get remarried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around Ted's  office) Boy, I bet you if mommy ever saw  this she'd remarried you.

dialogues.speaker: AN ALARM CLOCK THAT SITS ON A NIGHTSTAND
dialogues.text: As it rings, THE CAMERA PANS ACROSS and we SEE Joanna sit in bed wide awake, smoking. As she puts out the cigarette she has been smoking and starts to get out of bed,

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Who stands with a cup of coffee in his hands, looking out the window, but not seeing anything. HOLD FOR A BEAT, the he checks his watch and starts for the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: As she selects a very conservative suit from her closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted, now fully dressed, wearing a dark blue suit, whit shirt, conservative tie, leans over Billy and wakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna sits across from her lawyer as he talks to her,  intently, giving her last-minute instructions.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED KRAMER
dialogues.text: Taking Billy to school. They stop at the entrance, Ted ki his son good-bye and stands for a moment watching as the runs into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bleak January morning, the streets around the  courthouse are mobbed with people on their way to work. W SEE Ted Kramer, a tiny figure among hundreds, coming out the subway. He crosses the street and starts up the steps the large and forbidding courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted gets off the elevator and starts down the corridor toward the courtroom. In the f.g., В– standing by the doo the courtroom itself is John Shaunessy, he greets Ted, th shake hands and talk together for a moment. Then, as they enter the courtroom:

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As Ted enters, looks around. Mrs. Willewska sits in one o the back rows, wearing her best Easter hat. Ted pauses by her, thanks her for coming. Several rows in front of her is Thelma. Ted crosses to he they talk quietly between themselves for a few moments. T Ted moves on to a table at the front of the room where Jo Shaunessy waits.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DOORS AT THE BACK OF THE COURTROOM
dialogues.text: As they swing open and Joanna, along with her lawyer, a M GRESSEN. THE CAMERA PANS WITH THEM as they walk to the fr of the room and take their seats at the table opposite Te and his lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oyez, oyez... The third Circuit Court  of the State of New York, Judge Atkins  presiding is now in session. All  rise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the judge enters, takes his seat. Opening business of the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gressen (Joanna's lawyer) gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor. As our first witness I  would like to call Joanna Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lawyer leans across to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stage whisper) Real direct. Motherhood... They're  going right for the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Joanna gets to her feet, crosses to the witness stand is sworn in. Note: Throughout the following, we continually CROSS-CUT Ted Kramer, leaning forward, listening intently. It becom evident that, in spite of himself, there are moments he f great compassion for Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, would you  tell the court how long you were  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And would you describe those years  as happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first couple, yes, but after  that it became increasingly difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kramer, did you ever work in a  job while you were married to your  ex-husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you wish to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I tried to talk to Ted В– my ex- husband В– about it, but he wouldn't  listen. He refuses to discuss it in  any serious way. I remember one time  he said I probably couldn't get a  job that would pay enough to hire a  baby-sitter for Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Mrs. Kramer, are you employed  at the present time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I work for Jantzen as a  sportswear designer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is your present salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make thirty-one thousand dollars a  year.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching tactics) Mrs. Kramer, do you love your child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Yes. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet you chose to leave him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking carefully,  with great thought) Yes... Look, during the last five  years we were married, I had... I  was getting more and more... unhappy,  more and more frustrated. I needed  to talk to somebody. I needed to  find out if it was me, if I was going  crazy or what. But every time I turned  to Ted В– my ex-husband, he couldn't  handle it. He became very... I don't  know, very threatened. I mean,  whenever I would bring up anything  he would act like it was some kind  of personal attack. Anyway, we became  more and more separate... more and  more isolated from one another.  Finally, I had no other choice, I  had to leave. And because of my ex- husband's attitude В– his unwillingness  to deal with my feelings, I had come  to have almost no self-esteem... (with feeling) At the time I left, I sincerely  believed that there was something  wrong with me В– that my son would be  better off without me. It was only  when I got to California and started  into therapy I began to realize I  wasn't a terrible person. And that  just because I needed some creative  and emotional outlet other than my  child, that didn't make me unfit to  be a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge) Your honor, I would like to place in  evidence a report on Mrs. Kramer's  therapy by her therapist, Dr. Elinore  Freedman of La Jolla, California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that he hands both the judge and Shaunessy a thi sheaf of papers. Then, turning his attention back to Joan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, why did you set up  residence in New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my son is here. And his father  is here. As a mother, I don't want  my child to be separated from his  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kramer, can you tell the court  why you are asking for custody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's my child... Because I  love him. I know I left my son, I  know that's a terrible thing to do.  Believe me, I have to live with that  every day of my life. But just because  I'm a woman, don't I have a right to  the same hopes and dreams as a man?  Don't I have a right to a life of my  own? Is that so awful? Is my pain  any less just because I'm a woman?  Are my feelings any cheaper? I left  my child В– I know there is no excuse  for that. But since then, I have  gotten help. I have worked hard to  become a whole human being. I don't  think I should be punished for that.  I don't think my son should be  punished for that. Billy's only six.  He needs me. I'm not saying he doesn't  need his father, but he needs me  more. I'm his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Kramer. I have no  further questions.

dialogues.speaker: ON SHAUNESSY
dialogues.text: As he stands, collects his papers from the table and, tak his own sweet time, crosses to Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, Mrs. Kramer, you said you  were married seven years. Is that  correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all that time did your husband  ever strike you or abuse you  physically in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your husband strike or physically  abuse his child in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you describe your husband as  an alcoholic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy drinker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he unfaithful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he ever fail to provide for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wry smile) Well, I can certainly understand why  you left him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching his line  of questioning) How long do you plan to live in New  York, Mrs. Kramer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permanently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: During the early part of Shaunessy's cross-examinat Joanna has been very forthright, very sure of herself. No as he starts getting tougher, she begins to falter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permanently? (smiles, like a shark  smiles) Mrs. Kramer, how many boy friends  have you had В– permanently?

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: Her head snaps back as though she's been hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boring in) How many lovers have you had В–  permanently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks toward Gressen  for help) I don't recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than three, less than thirty- three В– permanently?

dialogues.speaker: ON GRESSEN
dialogues.text: He is again on his feet, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overruled. The witness will answer,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) Somewhere in between.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a lover now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge) Your honor, I would request a direct  answer to a direct question. Does  she have a lover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll allow that. The witness will  answer please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that... permanent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by now she is becoming  thoroughly rattled) I... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, we don't really know, do we,  when you say "permanently" if you're  planning to remain in New York, or  even to keep the child for that  matter, since you've never really  done anything in your life that was  continuing, stable, that could be  regarded as permanent.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PETITIONER'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Gressen jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection! I must ask that the counsel  be prevented from harassing the  witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a new attack) Mrs. Kramer, how can you consider  yourself a fit mother when you have  been a failure at virtually every  relationship you have undertaken as  an adult?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (red in the face) Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ask it another way. What was  the longest personal relationship  you have had in your life В– other  than parents and girlfriends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattled) Ah... I guess I'd have to say...  with my child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wonder, irony) Whom you've seen twice in a year?  Mrs. Kramer, your ex-husband, wasn't  he the longest personal relationship  in your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) I suppose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you speak up, Mrs. Kramer? I  couldn't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were married two years before the  baby. And then four very difficult  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you were a failure at the longest,  most important relationship in your  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overruled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not a failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh? What do you call it then В– a  success? The marriage ended in  divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (so angry she forgets  her cool) I consider it less my failure than  his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seizes on this) Congratulations, Mrs. Kramer. You  have just rewritten matrimonial law.  You were both divorced, Mrs. Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his feet) Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge) Your honor, I'd like to ask what  this model of stability and  respectability has ever succeeded  at? (to Joanna) Mrs. Kramer, were you a failure at  the longest, most important personal  relationship in your life?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Who sits silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please answer the question, Mrs.  Kramer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper) It did not succeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly fierce) Not it... Not it, Mrs. Kramer В– you.  Were you a failure at the most  important personal relationship of  your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaunessy smiles, turns his back on Joanna and walks back toward the respondent's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Shaunessy sits down next to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over, in a  whisper) Jesus Christ. Did you have to be so  rough on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tough) Do you want the kid or don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ON JOANNA
dialogues.text: Shaken, she gets down from the witness stand, crosses to petitioner's table without looking at Ted. She sits, lean across to her lawyer and whispers something in his ear. A he nods...

dialogues.speaker: ON JIM O'CONNOR
dialogues.text: Who sits in the witness stand. At the moment he is being  examined by Gressen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, Mr. O'Connor, how long did  Ted Kramer work for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight, almost nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you have a close personal  relationship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how did you find his work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was good. He was a hard worker, a  lot of drive, a real hustler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet you fired him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down) Ted was a good worker. But, ah...  after his wife left him and he was  taking care of the kid on his own,  things started to change. Look, I  know he had problems, I understand  that. I've got problems, everybody's  got problems. But I've got a shop to  run, I can't let that kind of thing  get in the way... (quietly) I guess I felt that Ted was letting  his duties at home interfere with  his responsibilities in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I have no further  questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaunessy stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Connor, does the agency still  have the Fire and Ice account?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (up tight) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. O'Connor, can you tell me where  you are employed at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff) At the moment I am unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the petitioner has no further  witnesses, we will hear the respondent  tomorrow morning at 9:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits at the dining table poring over law books, writi copious notes on a legal pad. Billy sits across from him  drawing in a pad with magic markers. HOLD FOR A BEAT as B looks up at his father. It is clear that something is  bothering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom В– I mean, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Uh, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do when you were little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still involved in  his books) I guess about the same kind of things  you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you watch "I Dream of Jeannie?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Uh, uh... We didn't have television  then.

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Eyes wide. He finds this hard to believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have T.V.?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He looks up for the first time, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. It hadn't been invented yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is serious  business) Was there apple juice when you were  little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there was apple juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there Burger King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, uh. There was no such a thing as  Burger King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else wasn't there?

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He takes a long look at his son, then closes the law book puts his notes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see... There wasn't  McDonald's. And there wasn't  astronauts... And there wasn't frozen  yogurt. And there wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues on about what wasn't, we

dialogues.speaker: ON THELMA
dialogues.text: She sits in the witness stand being examined by Shaunessy From her attitude it is clear that she is very wrought up that all of this is taking a heavy emotional toll on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Phillips, how long have you  known Ted Kramer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six years. Ever since Ted and Joanna  moved into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often do you see Mr. Kramer and  his son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge, by way  of explanation) Charley, my husband, and I are...  divorced and Kim, that's our daughter  is about Billy's age and the children  play together a lot. So, I guess we  see each three or four times a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you describe the relationship  between Mr. Kramer and his son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. It's just beautiful.  They have a beautiful relationship.

dialogues.speaker: ON GRESSEN
dialogues.text: Getting wearily to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patronizing) Objection, your honor. The answer  is, to be generous, very vague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you recall any particular incident  that relates to Mr. Kramer's care of  his child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting a losing  battle with her  emotions) Ted В– Mr. Kramer, spends a great  deal of time with his child. I don't  just mean hours, I mean good time,  involved time. He reads to Billy.  They play together. They talk all  the time... (tears start) He is a very... kind man... a very...  devoted father, and... and... (she turns to Joanna) And Joanna if you ever saw them  together... there wouldn't be a trial  at all... (she breaks down,  weeping) Oh, shit... I'm sorry... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note: during this we cross-cut to Joanna, who sits, stari at her friend, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) No further questions. Thank you Mrs.  Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up  from his notes) No questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma leaves the stand and walks back to her seat.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED KRAMER
dialogues.text: Sitting in the witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kramer, would you tell the court  exactly why you want to retain custody  of your child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking quietly) When Joanna В– (to the judge,  correcting himself) В– my ex-wife В– when she was talking  before about how unhappy she was  during our marriage... Well, I guess  most of what she said was probably  true. There were a lot of things I  didn't understand В– a lot of things  I would do different if I could.
