Just like I guess there are a lot of  things Joanna wishes she could  change... But we can't. Some things,  once they are done, can't be undone.  Joanna says she loves Billy. I believe  she does. So do I. But the way it  was explained to me, that's not the  issue. The only thing that's supposed  to matter here is what's best for  Billy... When Joanna said why  shouldn't a woman have the same  ambitions as a man, I suppose she's  right. But by the same token what  law is it that says a woman is a  better parent simply by virtue of  her sex? I guess I've had to think a  lot about whatever it is that makes  somebody a good parent: constancy,  patience, understanding... love.  Where is it written that a man has  any less of those qualities than a  woman? Billy has a home with me,  I've tried to make it the best I  could. It's not perfect. I'm not a  perfect parent. (unconsciously echoing  something Joanna  said earlier) I don't have enough patience.  Sometimes I forget he's just a little  kid... But I love him... More than  anything in this world I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Kramer. No further  questions.

dialogues.speaker: ON GRESSEN
dialogues.text: As he gets up from the petitioner's table and crosses to witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard-lining it) Mr. Kramer, by any chance have you  ever had a woman in your bed while  your child was asleep in the next  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly) So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching to another  line of attack) Mr. Kramer, isn't it true that you  were fired from your last job not  more than six weeks ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not losing his cool) Technically, the agency lost a big  account and seventy four people were  let go. I was one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snotty) You were fired, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I'm with J. Walter Thompson  now. I don't think that will happen  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snide) Give them time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor! Counsel is  harassing the witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge, pettish) Your honor, I'm only examining the  man's employment record. He pretends  to fitness when he cannot hold a  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained.

dialogues.speaker: ON GRESSEN
dialogues.text: He is thoughtful for a moment, like a man trying to decid whether or not to drop the bomb. Then, turning back to Te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very tough) Mr. Kramer, did your child nearly  lose an eye when he was in your care?

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: Stunned. He looks across at Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT
dialogues.text: Joanna looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (boring in) Mr. Kramer, did you, or did you not  tell the child's mother that you  were responsible for the injury that  permanently disfigured your child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaunessy is on his feet racing toward the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vehement) Objection! Your honor, counsel is  raising a question that is not germane  to these proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the judge) While the child was in the care of  the witness, he cut his face badly  and is now scarred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gressen) Are you introducing the question of  negligence here, counselor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Well, you'll have to do better  than that. Do you have any affidavits  to support negligence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not, your honor, however В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an isolated incident,  counselor, unless you can prove  otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Ted) Does the witness deny the injury  took place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before Ted can say  anything) No, counselor, I'm going to over- rule you on this line of questioning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I have concluded my questions.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PETITIONER'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Joanna sits, still not looking at Ted. She holds her face one hand shielding her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JUDGE
dialogues.text: As he makes his closing statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaunessy and Ted stand talking, reviewing the case. Then the two men shake hands, the lawyer waves goodbye, turns starts back into the building. THE CAMERA PANS WITH TED a he walks toward the main exit.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: As he comes out of the building, starts down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, turns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, standing waiting for him is Joanna.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: His face a mask of cold anger. She crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I just mentioned it in  passing. I never thought he'd use  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah, well he did, didn't he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Ted. I never would have  brought it up if I thought В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested, Joanna. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns and walks away from her, leaving her standing watching him as he disappears.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND THELMA
dialogues.text: It is a bleak winter's day. THE CAMERA TRACKS WITH THEM a they walk along, Ted carrying a bag of groceries, Thelma  with cleaning. The children run around them, playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard anything yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Any day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for several beats, each clearly lost their own thoughts. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Uh, huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is hard to say) Ah, Charley and I are... Well, we're  thinking about... I mean, actually  we're sort of talking about maybe  getting back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thunderstruck) You and Charley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conflicting emotions) Hey, that's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily) Maybe. I said maybe. (apologizing for her  good fortune) What I mean is, ah... I don't think  it'll really work out, but Charley  seems to want it, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the sentence unfinished. They walk in silence several more steps. Then she takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't help grinning) Oh, God... Ted, I am really scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for a beat, then Ted looks OFF SCREE spots something:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Saturday Father, restless, bored, walking with his  daughter who is also bored. It is clear that they have no to say to one another. He looks around, spots Ted, waves starts in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reacts as though he has seen a vision of his own death

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Thelma, urgent) C'mon. (to Billy and Kim) Billy, Kim. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted ushers them across the street, away from the Satur Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowded, rather posh watering spot. Shaunessy sits alon at a table for two, a drink in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON THE DOOR
dialogues.text: As Ted enters, spots Shaunessy and starts in his directio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: ON SHAUNESSY
dialogues.text: As he looks up at Ted, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He realizes that they have lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge went for motherhood straight  down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost him? I lost him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how sorry I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from a piece  of paper) Ordered, adjudged and decreed that  the petitioner be awarded custody of  the minor child, effective Monday  the 23rd of January. That the  respondent pay for the maintenance  and support of said child, four  hundred dollars each month. That the  father shall have the following rights  of visitation: every other weekend,  one night each week to be mutually  agreed upon and one half of the  child's vacation period. (looks up at Ted) That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grim) What if I fight it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of factly) We can appeal, but I can't guarantee  anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determined) I'll take my chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his mind is made up) Don't worry. I'll get the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to tell you something, Ted.  This time it'll be Billy that pays.  This time I'll have to put him on  the stand.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: As his last hope goes crashing to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ no... I can't do that. I  just... can't... (he looks up at the  lawyer in despair) Excuse me... I'm sorry... I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is all Ted can manage to say. He gets to his feet an rushes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Willewska comes out. Her eyes are red from crying THE CAMERA PANS WITH HER as she turns up the street on he way to pick up Billy from school. THE CAMERA HOLDS IN POS as she meets Thelma. They stand talking for a moment, the Thelma turns and starts to run toward the building.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: They open and Thelma steps out. She runs to the door, beg to knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Ted!... It's me... Ted?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a beat of silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quiet) Please go away, Thel... I... I just  have to be by myself for a little  while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I just heard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Thel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thelma leans against the door and begins to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so... sorry... Oh, Ted, I'm so  sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Willewska brings Billy back from school.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: It opens and Billy and Mrs. Willewska enter. Billy sees T and rushes across to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Daddy! You're home early. Did you  get fired again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing in spite of  himself) No, son, I didn't get fired. (fake cheerful) I'll tell you what we'll do, okay?  How about if we go to a Burger King  and then we watch a little T.V. and  then we get packed to go to the  country tomorrow. Just you and me...  How 'bout that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD FOR A BEAT, then:

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: He sits at the dining table, a typewriter in front of him As he begins to type, hunt and peck system, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The page in the typewriter. We SEE and HEAR at the same t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna... This is by way of  introducing William Kramer. He is a  sweet child, as you will see. He is  allergic to grape juice, but will  more than make up for the loss in  apple juice. He is also allergic to  peanut butter from the health food  store, but not from the supermarket.  Don't ask me why.

dialogues.speaker: ON A CORNER MAILBOX
dialogues.text: As Ted mails the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At times, in the night he will have  nightmares, one particular monster  is called The Face. The Face, as  best as I can determine, looks like  a circus clown without a body, and  from what the pediatrician says, and  what I have read, may be sexual fear  of losing his penis, or a fear of  his own anger, or just a circus clown  he saw once.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SAME MAILBOX
dialogues.text: As a sack of mail is loaded into a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His doctor, by the way, is still Ed  Davies. The Sundafed is for colds,  one tablespoon every four hours. I  will pack it in the blue suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POSTMAN enters the building carrying a bag of mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His best stories have been Babar and  Winnie the Pooh up to now, with Batman  moving up. His housekeeper has been  Etta Willewska and she is the main  reason for the note. She is a loving  woman, conscientious, very concerned  about Billy and more important, Billy  cares about her.

dialogues.speaker: ON A STACK OF MAIL
dialogues.text: As it is dropped in front of a doorway. We SEE that the l from Ted to Joanna is on top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I urge you to retain her. Her number  is 722-8099, and I think she will  take the job if it is offered. I'm  sure other things will come up. Ask  me what you need to and I guess  eventually we'll talk...

dialogues.speaker: ON HER
dialogues.text: As she finishes reading the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I can think of, except to  repeat what I said before, he's a  terrific kid. I'm grateful for the  time we've had together and I feel I  am a better man because of my son...  Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a clear, cold beautiful winter's day. Ted and Billy walk along the beach at the edge of the water. THE CAMERA TRAC WITH THEM. There are several beats of silence as Ted trie to think of how to begin. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, sometimes when a mother and a  father are divorced, there's a  discussion about who the child should  live with, the mother or the father.  Now there is a man who is very wise.  He's called a judge. And a judge has  a lot of experience with divorces  and he decides who it would be best  for the child to live with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he decide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... Well, that's what he does.  He's a very powerful man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a principal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigger than a principal. The judge  sits in robes in a big chair... The  judge has thought a lot about us,  about you and me and your mom, and  he has decided... (a deep breath) ...he has decided that it would be  best for you to live with your mom  Joanna in her apartment. (fake cheerful) And I'm very lucky. Because even  though you'll live with your mom  Joanna I'll get to see you once a  week for dinner and a couple of  weekends a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying very hard not  to cry) What don't you understand, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will my bed be, where will I  sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At your mom's. She'll have a bed for  you in your own room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will my toys be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send your toys there and I'm  sure you'll get some new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will read me my stories?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Daddy, what if The Face comes when  I'm at mommy's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mom knows all about The Face,  okay? Don't worry, she'll tell The  Face to beat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come and say good-night to  me every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Ted can't stand it any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's getting cold. Why don't  you go inside where it's warm. I'll  be along in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy hangs back, watching Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, scoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy turns and runs back along the beach toward the ho Then, he stops, turns back to look once more at his fathe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands at the ocean's edge, his back to CAMERA, weepi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND BILLY
dialogues.text: They stand side by side, like a surgeon and his assistant Spread out on the counter in front of them are the making of French toast. The following is done with great efficie in contrast to the first time we saw them go through the  same ritual. They work in silence except for an occasiona command. Each concentrating on this last moment of closen each doing his best to avoid thinking about Billy's depar Finally:

dialogues.speaker: ON BILLY
dialogues.text: Looking at his father, trying to memorize the older man's face. Ted turns, sees his son watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with false gaiety) Hey? What's doin' with that bread?  Let's see a little hustle around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's bags are packed and stacked neatly in the living  room. Nearby, Billy and his father sit, silent, waiting. Sound-effect: The intercom from the lobby buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at his son, smiles. The boy smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, fighting back tears, nods. Sound-effect: The intercom buzzes again. Ted gets to his feet and starts toward the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted picks up the intercom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, it's Joanna. Can you meet me in  the lobby?... Alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she hangs up before he can answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Willewska,  in the kitchen) I'll be back in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ELEVATOR DOORS
dialogues.text: As they open, Ted steps out, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby is dark, the only light coming from the window. Joanna sits off to one side, wearing sunglasses. She look up as Ted approaches, a small smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abrupt) Okay, I'm here. Now why did you В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Joanna. What the В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistent) Ted, do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love him too... I don't think I  ever knew how much until now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long pause as she looks at Ted, unable to spea Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a deep breath, then:) Ted, when we got married it was  because I was twenty-seven years old  and I thought I should get married  and... when I had Billy it was because  I thought I should have a baby...  and I guess all I did was mess up my  life and your life and В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna, what the hell is В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) Please... Please don't stop me. This  is the hardest thing I've ever had  to do..

dialogues.speaker: ON TED
dialogues.text: Struck by the urgency in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I left... when I was in  California, I began to think, what  kind of mother was I that I could  walk out on my own child. It got to  where I couldn't tell anybody about  Billy В– I couldn't stand that look  in their faces when I said he wasn't  living with me. Finally it seemed  like the most important thing in the  world to come back here and prove to  Billy and to me and to the world how  much I loved him... And I did... And  I won. Only... it was just another  "should." (she begins to break  down) ...Sitting in that courtroom. Hearing  everything you did, everything you  went through... Something happened.  I guess it doesn't matter how much I  love him, or how much you love him.  I guess it's like you said, the only  thing that counts is what's best for  Billy. I don't know, maybe that's  all love is anyway... Ted, I think  Billy should stay with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she reaches out,  takes his hand) He's already got one mother, he  doesn't need two... He's yours... (her last ounce of  reserve crumbles) I won't fight you for him any more.  He's yours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... Oh, my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only can I still see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more waiting in Coffee Shops... I  promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna's last ounce of reserve crumbles, she begins to so Ted puts his arms around her and holds her. They do not k Then, after a few moments she steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chin high) Okay... I think I'll go talk to my  son now. (wiping her eyes) How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into the elevator and, as the doors close, bloc them from view, we...

dialogues.speaker: ON TED AND BILLY
dialogues.text: TRACKING JUST IN FRONT OF THEM as they walk to the park.  They are deep in conversation, although we are too far aw to bear what they are saying. HOLD ON THEM and, as they r the entrance to the park, Billy first, then Ted begin to  run, overwhelmed with the sheer joy of being alive, of be together. As they continue to run, THE CAMERA PULLS BACK UP AND WE SEE that they are only two among thousands of  parents and children in Central Park on a sunny afternoon THE CAMERA CONTINUES TO PULL BACK until they are lost fro view and it is...
